column1:
"in  a  case  dependent  wholly  on  circumstantial  evidence 
the  Court  must  be

a) 
that  the  circumstances  from  which  the 
interference  of guilt 
is 
to  be
drawn,  have  been fully  established by unimpeachable  evidence  beyond

tendency  unerringly 
a) 
that 
the 
circumstances 
are  of  a  determinative
pointing towards the guilt of the accused; and

b) 
that  the  circumstances,  taken  collectively,  are  incapable  of explanation
on  any reasonable  hypothesis  save that of the  guilt sought to  be proved
